unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked me about the evolution of internet terms in India, especially for us older folks who are still trying to wrap our heads around some of this stuff. It's quite a ride, honestly!
normalised: Okay, so someone asked me about the evolution of internet terms in India, especially for us older folks who are still trying to wrap our heads around some of this stuff. It is quite a ride, honestly!

unnormalised: I remember back in the day, like, early 2000s, 'internet' itself was this magical, mysterious thing. We’d go to cyber cafes and pay Rs. 20 per hour to 'surf the net'. Emails were the big deal then – finally, a way to send letters faster than India Post! 'cc' and 'bcc' were just becoming common, and everyone was obsessed with getting a 'dot com' address. Getting online meant hearing that dial-up modem screech… ugh, the memories. Things like "www" felt like some serious tech jargon.
normalised: I remember back in the day, like, early two thousands, 'internet' itself was this magical, mysterious thing. We would go to cyber cafes and pay rupees twenty per hour to 'surf the net'. Emails were the big deal then – finally, a way to send letters faster than India Post! 'c-c' and 'b-c-c' were just becoming common, and everyone was obsessed with getting a 'dot com' address. Getting online meant hearing that dial-up modem screech… ugh, the memories. Things like "w-w-w" felt like some serious tech jargon.

unnormalised: Then came the social media boom. Suddenly, everyone was on Orkut, then Facebook. That’s when abbreviations started taking over. 'LOL' became part of our vocabulary, even my mom started using it, though she thought it meant 'lots of love' initially. 'BRB', 'OMG', all this new internet slang was spreading like wildfire. We went from checking emails once a day to checking Facebook every 5 mins. It was all about connecting, liking, and sharing. "FB" was the new cool.
normalised: Then came the social media boom. Suddenly, everyone was on Orkut, then Facebook. That is when abbreviations started taking over. 'L-O-L' became part of our vocabulary, even my mom started using it, though she thought it meant 'lots of love' initially. 'B-R-B', 'O-M-G', all this new internet slang was spreading like wildfire. We went from checking emails once a day to checking Facebook every five minutes. It was all about connecting, liking, and sharing. "F-B" was the new cool.

unnormalised: Now, with the rise of mobile internet and Jio, things have gone completely next level. We have 4G, soon 5G, and data is cheaper than ever. Terms like 'WiFi', 'hotspot', and 'data pack' are household names. Everyone is using WhatsApp, and it's all about GIFs and stickers. I can't even keep up with the new acronyms anymore. "DM", "TBT," and all sorts of trendy lingo fill the online spaces and kids these days just throw around things like "IYKYK" without any further explanation.
normalised: Now, with the rise of mobile internet and Jio, things have gone completely next level. We have four G, soon five G, and data is cheaper than ever. Terms like 'W-i-F-i', 'hotspot', and 'data pack' are household names. Everyone is using WhatsApp, and it is all about G-I-F-s and stickers. I cannot even keep up with the new acronyms anymore. "D-M", "T-B-T," and all sorts of trendy lingo fill the online spaces and kids these days just throw around things like "I-Y-K-Y-K" without any further explanation.

unnormalised: It's funny how these terms evolve. From serious tech language to abbreviations to memes, it all reflects how quickly technology is changing our lives here in India. I guess the key is to keep learning, keep asking questions (even if they sound silly), and embrace the digital world, one acronym at a time!
